projectDesc.p: "Everything destines toward demise" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: كل شيء مصيره للزوالغير ربي وصالح الأعمال
app.rdg:
Everything destines toward demise
Besides my Master and good works.

app.lem: وترى الناس ينظرون جميعاليس فيهم لذاك بعض احتيال
app.rdg:
You see the people, all looking,
Unable to cheat their demise.

app.lem: قل لأم الأغرِّ تبكي بُجَيْراًحيل بين الرجال والأموال
app.rdg:
Tell the highborn’s mother, mourning Bujayr,
A barrier’s set between men and their wealth.

app.lem: ولعمري لأبكينَّ بُجَيْراًما أتى الماء من رؤوس الجبال
app.rdg:
I’ll mourn Bujayr, by my life,
As water runs from mountain heads.

app.lem: لهف نفسي على بُجيْرٍ إذا ماجالت الخيلُ يوم حربٍ عُضال
app.rdg:
My misery, Bujayr, when
Horses coursed, a hard war day.

app.lem: وتساقى الكُماةُ سُمًّا نقيعاًوبدا البيضُ من قباب الحِجَال
app.rdg:
The courageous exchanged fatal raids.
Whites appeared from canopies’ bellies,
“Whites” here perhaps refers to the warriors’ unsheathed, shining weapons, or more likely to the faces of the Banī Bakr’s women, peeking out of their enclosures. This latter reading lends itself to the verse that follows, as it does the legend of al-Ḥārith’s entrance into the fight. As medieval commentators have it, the fateful day he joined the battle would be remembered as the Day of Shearing (Yawm al-Taḥāluq), or the Day of Haircutting Past the Earlobes (Yawm Taḥlāq al-Limam), on account of Bakr’s cutting their hair in order for their women to identify them on the battlefield: al-Ḥārith had ordered them to attend the battle to finish off Taghlib’s wounded and nurse their own. The white faces may also refer to Taghlib’s own women, about to be despoiled.

app.lem: وسَعَتْ كلُّ حُرَّة الوجهِ تدعويا لبكرٍ غرَّاءَ كالتِّمثال
app.rdg:
Every freewoman raced, calling,
“Bakr!”—comparably honorable.

app.lem: يا بجيرَ الخيرات لا صُلحَ حتىنملا البيد من رؤوس الرجال
app.rdg:
Best Bujayr, no peace until
We fill the wasteland with men’s heads.

app.lem: وتَقَرَّ العيونُ بعد بُكاهاحين تسقي الدّما صدورَ العوالي
app.rdg:
Eyes will smile after crying
Once blood quenches arrowheads.

app.lem: صْبَحَتْ وائلٌ تَعِجُّ من الحربِ عجيجَ الجمال بالأثقال
app.rdg:
Wāʾil’s children wailed from war,
Wāʾil being the parent of Taghlib and Bakr. See Introduction.
The wailing of encumbered camels.

app.lem: لم أكُنْ من جُناتِها عَلِمَ اللهُوإنِّي لَحِرِّها اليوم صال
app.rdg:
I played no part in this war, Allāh knows;
I feel its heat today.

app.lem: قد تجنّبت وائلاً كي يُفيقوافأبت تغلب عليَّ اعتزالي
app.rdg:
I avoided Wāʾil that they might come around,
But Taghlib refused my seclusion.

app.lem: وأشابوا ذُؤَابَتي ببجيرٍقتلوه ظُلماً بغير قتال
app.rdg:
They greyed my forelock with Bujayr,
Killed him wrongly, without cause.

app.lem: قتلوه بِشِسْعِ نَعْلِ كُليبٍإنّ قَتْلَ الكريمِ بالشِّسْعِ غالِ
app.rdg:
Killed him in exchange for Kulayb’s lace—
The noble’s killing for string’s expensive!

app.lem: يا بني تغلبٍ خذوا الحِذر إنَّاقد شربنا بكأس موتٍ زُلال
app.rdg:
Banī Taghlib! Take heed:
We drank pure Death indeed.

app.lem: يا بني تغلبٍ قتلتُم قتيلاًما سمعنا بمثله في الخوالي
app.rdg:
Banī Taghlib! You killed a precious slain,
We haven’t heard his likes before.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيلقِحَتْ حرْبُ وائلٍ عن حِيالِ
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
In the original Arabic, the repeated command verb employed, “qarribā,” takes the dual form, although a plural audience is targeted. Classical Arabic poets rely on this addressing of two imaginary bystanders for dramatic effect, most famously Imruʾ al-Qays (d.c.545) in his ode’s opening, “Qifā nabki min dhikrā ḥabīb wa-manzili” (“Stop! Let’s weep, recalling lover and lodge”).
Wāʾil’s war bore fruit, after infertility.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيليس قولي يُرادُ لكنْ فِعَالي
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
I don’t mean words, but deeds.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيجَدَّ نَوْحُ النِّساءِ بالأعوالِ
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
The women’s wails turned earnest.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيشابَ رأسي وأنكرتني القوالي
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
My head greyed; haters knew me not.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيللسُّرى والغُدُوِّ والآصال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
For riding: nighttime, morning, afternoon.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيطال لَيْلي على اللّيالي الطِّوال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
My night’s surpassed the longest nights.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيلاعتناق الأبطال بالأبطال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
For engagement: Champions 'gainst Champions.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيواعْدِلا عن مقالَةِ الجُهَّال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
Discard the talk of the untaught.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيليس قلبي عن القتال بِسَال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
My heart will not forgo warring.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيكُلَّما هبَّ ريحُ ذَيْلِ الشَّمال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
Even as Boreas’ tailwind roared.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيلبجيرٍ مُفَكِّك الأغلال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
For Bujayr, Breaker of the chains.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيلكريمٍ مُتَوَّجٍ بالجمال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
For a noble, Beauty-crowned

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيلا نَبيعُ الرِّجال بيْعَ النِّعال
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
We don’t sell men the sale of shoes.
See Introduction.

app.lem: قرِّبا مربَطَ النَّعامة منّيلبجيرٍ فداهُ عَمِّي وخالي
app.rdg:
Draw Naʿāmah’s harness near—
For Bujayr, my uncles be ransomed!

app.lem: قرِّباها لِحَيِّ تغلِبَ شُوساًلاعتناق الكُماةِ يوم القتال
app.rdg:
Bring it— to haughty Taghlib,
For the braves’ embrace the day of battle.

app.lem: قرِّباها وقرِّبا لَأْمَتي دِرْعاً دِلاصاً تَرُدُّ حَدَّ النِّبال
app.rdg:
Bring it— and bring my breastplate,
A sleek cuirass, blunts arrows’ edge.

app.lem: قرِّباها بِمُرْهفاتٍ حدادٍلِقِراعِ الأبطال يوم النِّزال
app.rdg:
Bring it— with slashing swords,
For the clash of heavies on battle day.

app.lem: رُبَّ جيشٍ لَقِيتُهُ يَمطُرُ المَوْتَ على هيْكَلٍ خفيفِ الجِلال
app.rdg:
Likely I faced an army, hurling
Death from lightly-armored chargers.

app.lem: سائِلوا كِنْدَةَ الكِرامَ وبكراًواسألوا مَذْحِجاً وحيَّ هلال
app.rdg:
Ask noble Kinda, inquire into Bakr,
Interrogate Madhḥij and Hilāl.
Kinda, Bakr, Madhḥij, Hilāl: notable Arabian tribes.

app.lem: إذ أتَوْنا بعسْكَرٍ ذي زُههاءٍمُكْفَهِرِّ الأذى شديدِ المَصال
app.rdg:
When they reached us with a massive troop,
Ready to attack, severe in their seizure;

app.lem: فَقَرَيْناه حين رام قِراناكُلَّ ماضي الذُّبابِ عضْبِ الصِّقال
app.rdg:
When they craved congress we met them,
Welcomed every keen sword’s edge.
